feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 17 at 11:37AM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: Heavy snowfall rates and strong winds will reduce visibilities to one half mile at times and cause drifting snow in the Kuskokwim Delta into this afternoon. Conditions will improve from west-to-east through the afternoon. As of late morning, the heaviest band of snow was inland near Bethel. Conditions in the Bethel area should improve by mid

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 17 at 11:27AM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Significant Snowfall Possible Sunday night to Tuesday... Heavy snowfall is possible Sunday night into Tuesday across the Central and Eastern Interior, including Fairbanks. Snowfall amounts of 6 to 12 inches will be possible over the two days. This weather system will also bring some warmer air into the area and the potential for some freezing rain, especially southwest of
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Interior; Deltana and Tanana Flats; Denali; Eastern Alaska Range; Middle Tanana Valley; Upper Koyukuk Valley; Upper Tanana Valley and the Fortymile Country; Yukon Flats and Surrounding Uplands

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 17 at 11:14AM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Elevated water levels in Norton Sound Region... A strong weather system moving to the West Coast will bring elevated water levels to the coast Sunday night and Monday in the Norton Sound Region. Water levels are expected to be 3 to 6 feet above the normal high tide line. Water levels will be similar to the system that brought
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Yukon Delta

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 17 at 5:07AM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Series of storms will impact the area into next week... A weather system moving through the Bering Sea will reach the Lower Yukon Delta this morning spreading snow to the area through the day. Snowfall with this system will spread north and east into Saturday with 3 to 8 inches of snowfall south of the Bering Strait by Saturday morning, with 1 to 4 inches of accumulation

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued December 17 at 8:54AM CST by NWS
entry.summary: ...COLD WEATHER WILL CAUSE ICE FORMATION ON THE MISSOURI RIVER... With another stretch of cold temperatures in store through the weekend and into next week, the Missouri River is making another attempt to initiate ice along the Burleigh and Morton counties reach of the river. Ice sheets are moving through the Bismarck and Mandan area of the river. What is uncertain is whether or not these ice

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued December 17 at 3:25AM PST until December 19 at 7:00AM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 4 AM SATURDAY TO 7 AM PST SUNDAY ALONG THE BASE OF THE WASHINGTON BLUE MOUNTAINS... * WHAT...South winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 55 mph expected along the base of the Blue Mountains. * WHERE...Foothills of the Blue Mountains of Washington, mainly east of Walla Walla.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Foothills of the Blue Mountains of Washington

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued December 17 at 3:22AM PST until December 19 at 10:00AM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...HEAVY SNOW POSSIBLE FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY MORNING... .A winter storm will spread snow into the Cascades Friday night with snow becoming heavy Saturday morning through Saturday night. Travel will be difficult over Stevens Pass with this winter storm. Snow is expected to decrease by late Sunday morning. ...WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING THROUGH SUNDAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued December 17 at 3:22AM PST until December 19 at 10:00AM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING THROUGH SUNDAY MORNING ABOVE 3000 FEET... * WHAT...Heavy snow possible above 3000 feet. Total snow accumulations of 3 to 31 inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph. * WHERE...Olympic mountains and valleys, including Hurricane
entry.cap:areaDesc: Olympics; West Slopes North Cascades and Passes; West Slopes North Central Cascades and Passes; West Slopes South Central Cascades and Passes
